newsitem.title: NIGERIA: NIGERIA FREES ANOTHER JOURNALIST FROM DETENTION.
newsitem.headline: NIGERIA FREES ANOTHER JOURNALIST FROM DETENTION.

text.p: Nigeria has released a third journalist detained without charge for nearly a year, a week after two others held without trial were freed, the Vanguard newspaper reported on Thursday.
Vanguard said its defence correspondent, George Onah, was freed on Wednesday after 356 days in detention.
No reason had been given for his arrest. He was picked up in May last year after writing a story on retirements in the army.
"He was released to the warm embrace of his wife, Josephine and daughter Jennifer...George was picked up when she was a week old," wrote his paper.
Freelance journalist Ladi Olorunyomi, detained since March, and Godwin Agbroko, editor of the The Week magazine who had been in detention from December 1996, were freed last week.
Agbroko was detained when his magazine published reports of disagreements in the ruling military council.
Journalist groups have recently stepped up their campaign against the detentions.
Olorunyomi's husband Dapo, an editor of the opposition magazine The News, fled to the United States fearing arrest over reports in the magazine about a coup plot to topple the military government.

Another editor of the magazine is serving a long jail term with three other journalists over the alleged plot along with more than 30 former officers including retired General Olusegun Obasanjo, a former military ruler.
Nigeria's military government is under criticism at home and abroad over detentions without trial and the slow pace of its plan to return Africa's most populous nation to democracy.
